text: This is from backtesting. I feel it's too volatile to get some £££ on, but don't have enough data (yet) to verify longer term. What do you guys think?

elements.text: This is from backtesting. I feel it's too volatile to get some £££ on, but don't have enough data (yet) to verify longer term. What do you guys think?

text: FYI, it's a £2 BACK strategy using nothing but price data for triggers

elements.text: FYI, it's a £2 BACK strategy using nothing but price data for triggers

text: Looks like it’s too dependent on the occasional big win at long odds that you’re not going to be able to scale much beyond minimum stakes

elements.text: Looks like it’s too dependent on the occasional big win at long odds that you’re not going to be able to scale much beyond minimum stakes

text: What’s the time period?

elements.text: What’s the time period?

text: Is this backtesting with flumine? Does it remove matched bets from the order book to avoid double counting liquidity?

elements.text: Is this backtesting with flumine? Does it remove matched bets from the order book to avoid double counting liquidity?

text: Are you going to be able to stomach that drawdown to 0 in real play, and not switch it off after you see that? What's the actual strike rate Vs implied strike rate?

elements.text: Are you going to be able to stomach that drawdown to 0 in real play, and not switch it off after you see that? What's the actual strike rate Vs implied strike rate?

text: Also if you've tuned tour price triggers on this period that you've run the backtest over, it's not particularly reliable IMO - you ought to tune your triggers on a separate dataset and then actually perform your validation/backtest on unseen market data.

elements.text: Also if you've tuned tour price triggers on this period that you've run the backtest over, it's not particularly reliable IMO - you ought to tune your triggers on a separate dataset and then actually perform your validation/backtest on unseen market data.

text: I wouldn't want that for myself. Everything I've ever done yields less in real life than in simulation - I'd imagine most people (probably everyone) is the same. I bet that would go negative if you implemented it. Also is that net of comm?

elements.text: I wouldn't want that for myself. Everything I've ever done yields less in real life than in simulation - I'd imagine most people (probably everyone) is the same. I bet that would go negative if you implemented it. Also is that net of comm?

text: Are you able to share an example script to plot this diagram? I remembered <@UBS7QANF3> share it before, but cant find it anymore.

elements.text: Are you able to share an example script to plot this diagram? I remembered
share it before, but cant find it anymore.

text: Likely matching rate for those winning longshots will be far lower than the match rates for losing trades too, IMO

elements.text: Likely matching rate for those winning longshots will be far lower than the match rates for losing trades too, IMO

text: It's a simple pyplot. If you Google it, there are plenty of examples. Just build a list of values and push them to pyplot.

elements.text: It's a simple pyplot. If you Google it, there are plenty of examples. Just build a list of values and push them to pyplot.

text:
I agree with all of the above, which is why I wanted confirmation. It's a Flumine backtest, so no commission. I have about 1200 UK horse racing markets at present, so the graph represents that full dataset as I currently have nothing else to test against.
<@UBS7QANF3> not sure what you mean regarding "remove matched bets to avoid double counting liquidity"? It's a Flumine backtest, so I'm just relying on the simulated matching, assuming it was already catered for?
The strategy is still very raw, i.e. unrefined as I threw it together just to get a ballpark figure, so it may be fine tuneable.

elements.text: I agree with all of the above, which is why I wanted confirmation. It's a Flumine backtest, so no commission. I have about 1200 UK horse racing markets at present, so the graph represents that full dataset as I currently have nothing else to test against.

not sure what you mean regarding "remove matched bets to avoid double counting liquidity"? It's a Flumine backtest, so I'm just relying on the simulated matching, assuming it was already catered for?
The strategy is still very raw, i.e. unrefined as I threw it together just to get a ballpark figure, so it may be fine tuneable.

text: I don’t use flumine so I don’t know how things are implemented but I mean ensuring that if you take £2 of liquidity that it’s not there for you to take it again

elements.text: I don’t use flumine so I don’t know how things are implemented but I mean ensuring that if you take £2 of liquidity that it’s not there for you to take it again

text: Hard to see from resolution, but that chart looks like it could look a lot different if you excluded 2-3 of your top priced winning backs? I often randomise ordered profit data like this and plot it several times - purely for psychological reasons really.

elements.text: Hard to see from resolution, but that chart looks like it could look a lot different if you excluded 2-3 of your top priced winning backs? I often randomise ordered profit data like this and plot it several times - purely for psychological reasons really.

text: <@UGV299K6H> I've generally found the same thing, but I've only recently started using Flumine because it has a simulated matching engine and I recall <@U4H19D1D2> saying it tends to underplay the matching.

elements.text: I've generally found the same thing, but I've only recently started using Flumine because it has a simulated matching engine and I recall
saying it tends to underplay the matching.

text: I think it's more fundamental than just the matching. Assuming that you research a number of ideas and chose the most promising - or tune some sort of selection criteria for the best results you'll find that you're favouring approaches that benefit from random variation over those that don't even if they're equally good/bad. Of course you can reduce this effect with various techniques but you can never fully escape it.

elements.text: I think it's more fundamental than just the matching. Assuming that you research a number of ideas and chose the most promising - or tune some sort of selection criteria for the best results you'll find that you're favouring approaches that benefit from random variation over those that don't even if they're equally good/bad. Of course you can reduce this effect with various techniques but you can never fully escape it.

text: Yeah, overfitting is a problem. I need to get a lot more data anyway, as 1200 markets is not really enough.

elements.text: Yeah, overfitting is a problem. I need to get a lot more data anyway, as 1200 markets is not really enough.

text: That looks like a tiny number of triggers for 1200 markets, obviously strategy dependant

text:
<@U4H19D1D2> I'm used to placing only a handful of bets per market, so thought I'd already "upgraded". :grinning: 
How many bets per market would be normal? The strategy is for inplay GB horse racing, an area that is totally new to me at present.

text: Depends how you're playing. I place a few hundred per event but I like to keep margins up. Others are real carpet bombers at lower margins.

elements.text: Depends how you're playing. I place a few hundred per event but I like to keep margins up. Others are real carpet bombers at lower margins.

text: So 1200 markets is basically a month, to put it simply I would want that pnl to be a dead straight line up

elements.text: So 1200 markets is basically a month, to put it simply I would want that pnl to be a dead straight line up

text: Not sure I'd say 'dead straight' but I would want a solidly upward line over that period.

elements.text: Not sure I'd say 'dead straight' but I would want a solidly upward line over that period.

text: Certainly if it's 1200 recent markets you'd have no excuses.

elements.text: Certainly if it's 1200 recent markets you'd have no excuses.

text: These are happy happy times.

elements.text: These are happy happy times.

text: Yeah, I'd prefer a less volatile line. I'm not having much success at this. Maybe my limit of £10 exposure per runner is holding me back?

elements.text: Yeah, I'd prefer a less volatile line. I'm not having much success at this. Maybe my limit of £10 exposure per runner is holding me back?

text: Yes and no - you should still be profitable.

elements.text: Yes and no - you should still be profitable.

text: <@UGV299K6H> At those kinds of numbers are you running market making strategies?

elements.text: At those kinds of numbers are you running market making strategies?

text: Kind of - I'm sort of a targeted market maker.

elements.text: Kind of - I'm sort of a targeted market maker.

text: I'm not just trying to make up the whole market, just spot where I can get a value bet in close up to what's being matched.

elements.text: I'm not just trying to make up the whole market, just spot where I can get a value bet in close up to what's being matched.

text: So I'll normally finish up with bets on 4 or 5 runners.

elements.text: So I'll normally finish up with bets on 4 or 5 runners.

text: Makes sense, that's the path I'm working towards, but still working on base strategies before trying to eek out the extra margin through market making

elements.text: Makes sense, that's the path I'm working towards, but still working on base strategies before trying to eek out the extra margin through market making

text: Not market making unless you're placing both passive back and lay on a selection :stuck_out_tongue_closed_eyes:

text: Ok - so maybe I'm not a market maker. I guess is depends on definitions.

text: I can tell you for certain what I'm not - I'm not a 'trader'.

text: Out of curiousity - what's your typical market share on a typical race? Something > 1 basis pt?

elements.text: Out of curiousity - what's your typical market share on a typical race? Something > 1 basis pt?

text: I'm not sure what you mean?

elements.text: I'm not sure what you mean?

text: Do you mean what proportion of what's traded on a market is me? If so it's not much.

elements.text: Do you mean what proportion of what's traded on a market is me? If so it's not much.

text: Ahh cool, fair enough

text: You just made me think about it and tot up a little bit. On a typical race something in the region of 1-2% of matched volume in running is me. Significantly less on the bigger events.

elements.text: You just made me think about it and tot up a little bit. On a typical race something in the region of 1-2% of matched volume in running is me. Significantly less on the bigger events.

text: So much for "not much"...that's massive! Niceeee :money_mouth_face:

text: That's a lot of capital to be employing.

text: Not really - sums matched in running are not that massive and nor is my outlay, it's the same money over and over. I have a couple of accounts and keep a £20k float in each. I used to use just one account and only keep £20k in that and I didn't bet any less but splitting bets between accounts makes the volatility on each balance a bit higher.
